title: Flood Risk Assessment
description: Computer vision system estimating ground-floor elevation from street-level imagery as an input for large-scale flood risk assessment.

modal.title: Flood Risk Assessment from Street View Imagery
modal.intro: For my <1>Bachelor Graduation Project</1>, I worked on a computer vision system that estimates the <1>ground-floor elevation of houses</1> from street-level imagery, as an input for <1>flood risk assessment</1>. Floods account for a large share of natural disasters worldwide, yet detailed elevation data is often costly or unavailable. This project explored whether <1>widely available street-view imagery</1> can help bridge part of that gap through a carefully designed, end-to-end pipeline.

features.title: Key Components
list: <1>End-to-end vision pipeline</1>: A three-stage system combining preprocessing, object detection, and post-processing to produce a single elevation estimate per image.
<1>Object detection model</1>: A YOLOv8-based detector trained on manually annotated street-view images to detect houses, doors, and steps across diverse urban environments.
<1>Post-processing beyond confidence scores</1>: Low confidence thresholds were used to maximize recall, followed by geometric filtering, clustering, and overlap removal to eliminate false positives.

<1>Structural reasoning in images</1>: Detected steps were grouped into staircases using density-based clustering, with scene-level constraints applied to select the staircase belonging to the centered house.

<1>Evaluation tied to the real problem</1>: Performance was assessed using both object-detection metrics (precision, recall, F1) and regression-style metrics (RMSE in number of steps), reflecting real-world flood risk usage.

impact.title: Results & Impact
text: The final system achieved a <1>precision of 0.908</1> for step detection and an <1>RMSE of 1.19 steps per image</1> on a held-out test set of 111 images, while remaining fast enough for large-scale analysis.

Rather than relying on a single modelâ€™s confidence, the project demonstrated how <1>engineering judgment and transparent post-processing</1> can compensate for limited data and imperfect detections, resulting in a system that is both interpretable and practically usable.
